history.overview: Historical overview of China from legendary origins to the contemporary era.

timeline.title: Origins and Neolithic Culture
timeline.desc: Cultures like Yangshao and Longshan develop agriculture, pottery, and complex settlements. These cultures set patterns of social organization and techniques that facilitated the emergence of early states and shared rituals.

timeline.title: Xia Dynasty (mythical)
timeline.desc: Traditionally considered the first dynasty; its historicity is debated. Beyond its historicity, its story serves as a moral framework for understanding the rise and fall of later dynasties.

timeline.title: Shang Dynasty
timeline.desc: Advanced bronze work, oracle bones engraved with archaic characters. Workshops and ritual centers show a specialized elite and regional exchange networks.

timeline.title: Zhou Dynasty (Western)
timeline.desc: Feudal system; legitimacy through the 'Mandate of Heaven' (天命). Rites and kinship structured political life, defining duties and hierarchies.

timeline.title: Zhou (Eastern): Spring and Autumn Period
timeline.desc: Political fragmentation; intellectual flourishing: Confucius, Laozi, Sunzi. Itinerant teachers advised kingdoms, leaving fundamental texts for Chinese philosophy.

timeline.title: Zhou (Eastern): Warring States Period
timeline.desc: Powerful states compete for hegemony; military and administrative innovation. Competition accelerated the professionalization of the bureaucracy and legal standardization.

timeline.title: Qin Unification
timeline.desc: Qin Shi Huang unifies China; standardizes writing, currency, and measures; beginning of major defensive works. Centralization allowed for large public works, although the harshness of policies generated resistance.

timeline.title: Han Dynasty (Western)
timeline.desc: Imperial consolidation; opening of the Silk Road; Confucian bureaucracy. Lasting institutions and a literate culture that would influence all of East Asia were consolidated.

timeline.title: Xin Interregnum and Han Restoration (Eastern)
timeline.desc: Brief Xin dynasty; subsequent Han restoration; cultural and scientific boom. The administration adapted to new social and economic realities after the crises.

timeline.title: Three Kingdoms
timeline.desc: Wei, Shu, and Wu compete; an era mythologized in classical literature. The popular memory of this era influenced theater, opera, and later stories.

timeline.title: Jin and Northern and Southern Dynasties
timeline.desc: Alternating control; Sinicization of non-Han peoples; development of Chinese Buddhism. The encounter between Han and non-Han traditions spurred artistic and religious innovations.

timeline.title: Sui Dynasty
timeline.desc: Reunification; Grand Canal; administrative reforms that pave the way for the Tang. The Grand Canal integrated regional economies and facilitated the supply of the capital.

timeline.title: Tang Dynasty
timeline.desc: Golden age of poetry and arts; Chang'an as a cosmopolitan metropolis; imperial examination (科举) is consolidated. Land and sea routes connected China with Central Asia, India, and the Islamic world.

timeline.title: Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms
timeline.desc: Cycle of ephemeral states and regionalism after the fall of the Tang. Political fragmentation did not prevent urban and commercial progress in several regions.

timeline.title: Song Dynasty (Northern and Southern)
timeline.desc: Innovations: gunpowder, compass, printing press; commercial boom; artistic refinement. Civil administration gained weight over the military, and private education expanded.

timeline.title: Mongol Rule: Yuan Dynasty
timeline.desc: Eurasian integration under the Mongols; intense contacts with the West. The mobility of artisans and astronomers led to technological and scientific transfers.

timeline.title: Ming Dynasty
timeline.desc: Han restoration; voyages of Zheng He; fortification of the Great Wall; artisanal splendor. Artisanal production and internal trade networks reached a large scale.

timeline.title: Qing Dynasty (Manchu)
timeline.desc: Territorial expansion; unequal encounters with Western powers; late reforms. Late reforms introduced railways, industries, and new educational institutions.

timeline.title: Republic of China
timeline.desc: End of the imperial system; internal conflicts and the Sino-Japanese War; uneven modernization. Intellectual debate renewed language, literature, and education, seeking to modernize the country.

timeline.title: People's Republic of China: early decades
timeline.desc: Industrialization; political campaigns; complex economic and social challenges. Literacy and public health advanced, despite political ups and downs.

timeline.title: Reforms and Opening Up
timeline.desc: Accelerated growth; urbanization; integration into the global economy; scientific and technological advances. Cities and social mobility grew, while challenges of inequality and sustainability emerged.

facts.title: Tones
facts.desc: Standard Mandarin has 4 tones and a neutral tone; the tonal contour changes the meaning. These aspects help to understand why learning Chinese combines writing, sound, and context.

facts.title: Logographic Writing
facts.desc: Each character (汉字) represents a syllable and a morpheme; they combine to form words. Each character usually corresponds to a syllable with meaning; combining them allows for the formation of new words and nuances.

facts.title: Pinyin
facts.desc: Transcription system to the Latin alphabet for learning pronunciation and typing. Mastering tone and rhyme in pinyin improves pronunciation and makes it easier to search and type on devices.

facts.title: Simplification
facts.desc: Since the mid-20th century, many strokes were simplified to speed up literacy. In practice, simplified and traditional characters coexist depending on the region and cultural context.

facts.title: Dialects
facts.desc: 'Chinese' groups families like Mandarin, Cantonese, Wu, Min... with large differences. They share a common written base, but oral intelligibility can be very low between different families.
